speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pain you're experiencing in your right groin area?

speaker: Patient
text: It's like a sharp stabbing sensation that comes and goes, but when it does, it's excruciating. I can barely walk without it feeling like a knife cutting through my thigh.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pain you're experiencing in your right groin area? Is it sharp, dull, or aching, and is it constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: It's sharp, and it really comes and goes, but when it does, it feels like my leg is being ripped apart.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when the pain started, was it immediately after the collision or did it develop over time?

speaker: Patient
text: It started immediately after the accident, I remember feeling a sudden jolt and then this searing pain in my right groin area. I didn't think much of it at the time, but the pain just intensified over the next few hours, and by the time I got home, I was barely able to put weight on my leg.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pain you're experiencing in your right groin area, and how does it relate to your abnormal leg positioning - does the pain seem to be triggered or worsened by certain movements?

speaker: Patient
text: It feels like the pain is really tied to the position of my leg, to be honest. When it's flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, the pain is more intense, and when I try to straighten it out, it's a bit more manageable. It's like my leg is trying to protect itself or something.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the pain when you move your right leg, does it feel like it's going to give way or is there a snapping or popping sensation?



Is there any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your right leg, particularly in the lower extremities?



Have you experienced any difficulty walking or bearing weight on your right leg after the collision?



REQUEST TEST: Electromyogram (EMG)

speaker: Measurement
text:
Musculoskeletal_Examination: 
Range_of_Motion: 
Right_Leg: Limited due to pain and abnormal positioning. The pain is more intense when the leg is flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, but it becomes more manageable when straightened. There is a sensation of the leg "protecting" itself.

Numbness, tingling, or weakness: None reported.

Difficulty walking or bearing weight: The patient experiences significant pain and difficulty walking without assistance.

RESULTS: 
Pelvic_X-ray: 
Findings: No fractures identified in the pelvic ring or femoral neck, but alignment suggests posterior dislocation of the right hip.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you describe the severity of the numbness, tingling, or weakness in your right leg, is it mild or severe, and does it radiate to other areas?



Also, I'd like to perform a physical examination. Please lift your right leg up for me, and I'll assess its range of motion and check for any swelling or bruising.

speaker: Patient
text: I didn't experience any numbness or tingling in my right leg, but I did mention that my right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, which feels uncomfortable. I don't feel like the numbness would be a major issue for me, though.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you lift your right leg up a bit higher for me, and I'd like to take a closer look at the area where the pain is located?



Also, I'd like to examine the area around your groin and check for any tenderness or swelling.

speaker: Patient
text: I'll try to lift it a bit higher for you. It's still a bit painful, but I'll manage.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'm going to take a closer look at the swelling and bruising on your right leg. Can you please spread your legs apart slightly so I can examine the area where your leg meets your body?

And can you tell me more about the abnormal leg positioning - how long have you been experiencing it, and is it constant or does it seem to change throughout the day?

speaker: Patient
text:
I've been noticing it since the accident, and it's been pretty consistent. When I'm sitting or standing, it feels like my leg is just a bit off, but when I'm lying down, it seems to feel better. I guess you could say it's always there, but it's more noticeable when I'm active.

And yeah, please go ahead and take a look at the swelling and bruising. I'm a bit worried about what I might find.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when the pain started, was it immediately after the collision or did it develop over time?

speaker: Patient
text: It started immediately after the accident, I remember feeling a sudden jolt and then this searing pain in my right groin area. I didn't think much of it at the time, but the pain just intensified over the next few hours, and by the time I got home, I was barely able to put weight on my leg.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the abnormal leg positioning - is it more pronounced when you're standing or sitting, and does it seem to be pulling the leg in any particular direction?

speaker: Patient
text: It's definitely more noticeable when I'm standing or walking, it feels like my leg is being pulled inward, like it's trying to get away from something. And yeah, it feels like it's pulling my leg into my body, that's the only way I can describe it.

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say it's a bit heavier, like there's a weight pulling me down, but when I sit down, it feels a bit more manageable. And yeah, the pain is really bad when I'm standing for long periods, but sitting or lying down seems to help a bit.

speaker: Doctor
text:

speaker: Patient
text:
I work as an elementary school teacher, so I'm on my feet a lot throughout the day, and I do have to stand for long periods while teaching classes. I try to take breaks and stretch when I can, but the pain is really bad when I'm standing for too long.

As for difficulty with urination or bowel movements, I haven't really noticed any issues, but I did have a bit of trouble getting up from the bathroom after the accident because of the pain in my right leg.

I'm a bit worried about what might be causing this, to be honest, and I'm hoping we can figure out what's going on so I can get back to my normal routine.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your responses. It seems like you've been experiencing a significant amount of pain and discomfort in your right groin area and leg, particularly after the rear-end collision. Can you tell me more about the sensations in your right leg when you're standing, is it heavier or lighter than when you're sitting?

speaker: Patient
text: It feels heavier, like there's a weight pulling me down, but when I sit down, it feels a bit more manageable.

speaker: Doctor
text:

Please describe any changes in sensation or pressure in your right leg when you shift your weight or move around.

speaker: Patient
text: When I shift my weight or move around, the sensation in my right leg seems to be even more pronounced. It's like my leg is trying to pull itself away from whatever it's sitting on, and it feels really unstable. When I'm standing, I can feel this pulling sensation, but when I sit down, it becomes more manageable, like my leg is finally able to relax a bit.
